name: Dhaka
fun_fact: Fun fact: Dhaka is the 'cycle rickshaw capital of the world' with over a million colorful three-wheeled pedicabs freely wandering the streetsâ€”over half of them in Dhaka! These hand-painted rickshaws are rolling works of art featuring movie stars, tigers, historical heroes, and floral patterns. In 2023, UNESCO inscribed Dhaka's rickshaws and rickshaw paintings on its list of intangible cultural heritage, recognizing this unique living pop art created by illiterate rickshaw artists who learn from masters.

hero_dishes.name: Fuchka (Pani Puri)
hero_dishes.description: Crispy hollow puris filled with spiced water, tamarind sauce, chickpeas, potatoesâ€”one of Bangladesh's most iconic street foods, sweet and sour with a hint of chili
hero_dishes.origin_story: Fuchka is beloved across Bangladesh and is the first thing locals think of for street food. Vendors now experiment with fusion versions like chicken fuchka or even chocolate fuchka, showing how the tradition evolves while maintaining Bengali flavors.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street vendors throughout Dhaka, especially in Mohammadpur, Mirpur, and Khilgaon areas; countless stalls in every neighborhood

hero_dishes.name: Chotpoti
hero_dishes.description: A blend of chickpeas, potatoes, and eggs topped with tamarind sauce, green chilies, and spices, often with crispy purisâ€”sweet, sour, and spicy
hero_dishes.origin_story: Along with fuchka, chotpoti is one of the most iconic street foods of Bangladesh. It represents the Bengali love for complex flavorsâ€”sweet tamarind, sour lime, spicy chilies, all in one bowl.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street food stalls everywhere, especially popular in university areas and busy markets

hero_dishes.name: Jhalmuri
hero_dishes.description: A shaken-together mix of peanuts, cucumbers, onions, chilies, tomatoes, puffed rice (muri), chanachur, and lemonâ€”extremely popular in Dhaka
hero_dishes.origin_story: People in Dhaka love jhalmuriâ€”it's the quintessential street snack. Vendors shake all ingredients together in a paper cone, creating a fresh, crunchy, spicy snack perfect for eating while walking.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street vendors on every corner, parks, markets, outside schools and offices

hero_dishes.name: Rice with Dal, Chicken, and Vegetables
hero_dishes.description: The daily staple: white rice with dal (lentil soup) to hold it together, pieces of chicken, potato, vegetable extrasâ€”what Bangladeshis actually eat daily
hero_dishes.origin_story: Rice is the staple food of Bangladesh, with fish the most common protein (though chicken is popular too). This simple meal represents authentic home cookingâ€”not fancy, just nourishing and essential. Dal binds the rice and adds protein.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Home cooking, local eateries (bhaat ghor), workers' lunch spots, family-run restaurants

hero_dishes.name: Halim
hero_dishes.description: Thick lentil soup with local spices and meat (mutton and/or beef), served hot from a large potâ€”essential to Bangladeshi street food
hero_dishes.origin_story: Halim is a hearty, slow-cooked dish brought to Bangladesh through Mughal influence. It's traditionally eaten during Ramadan for iftar, but street vendors serve it year-round, especially in the evening.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street food vendors with large pots, especially in Old Dhaka; popular during Ramadan

signature_drinks.name: Cha (Doodh Cha - Milk Tea)
signature_drinks.description: Thick, sweet, milky teaâ€”similar to Indian chai but with Bangladesh's unique earthy, creamy, spicy yet sweet taste
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Tea is the first thing people start their day with in Bengali families. There are 344,687 roadside tea stalls (tongs) across Bangladeshâ€”you don't need to walk more than a kilometer to find one. Locals greet each other by asking 'Chiya khanu vayo?' (Did you drink tea?). The tea culture involves long conversations at tong stalls, helping reduce daily stress. It's drunk throughout the dayâ€”morning wake-up, afternoon break, evening socializing.

signature_drinks.name: Malai Cha (Sweet Cream Tea)
signature_drinks.description: Special sweet tea made with thick cow's milkâ€”richer and creamier than regular cha
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Reserved for special occasions or when you want to treat yourself. The thick, creamy texture makes it almost dessert-like. Found at better tea stalls and traditional tea houses.

signature_drinks.name: Borhani
signature_drinks.description: Traditional spiced yogurt drink made from sour doi (yogurt), green chili, mustard seeds, black salt, coriander, and mint
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Commonly consumed in Dhaka and Chittagong, especially at weddings and iftar gatherings during Ramadan. It's drunk after heavy meals like biryani, morog polao (chicken pilaf), and tehari to aid digestion. The drink has Persian and Mughal origins but evolved into a uniquely Bengali creation.

food_culture_notes: It's normal to eat with your fingers instead of silverwareâ€”rice is shaped into balls
6 million people in Dhaka enjoy street food daily from 300,000 street vendors
Bangladeshis are fond of fried food: peyaju (lentil fritters), beguni (eggplant), chop (potato-egg)
Street food is affordable and convenient for rickshaw drivers, laborers, students, and workers
Everyone likes foreign food, but vendors add 'the taste of Bengal' to fusion dishes
Tea culture is intrinsic to the Bengali rhythm of lifeâ€”long conversations over tea
Pitha (traditional rice cakes) are made during festivals, especially in winter
Street vendors experiment with fusionâ€”chicken shawarmas with Bengali spices
